III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Hainley House is located on the west side of the center of campus. It is a one-story
building with no basement. The house has an entranceway/”mudroom” area with
lockers for coats, shoes, etc. There is a day area/living room in the front of the house
with an adjacent dining area and kitchen. Off the day area is a bathroom, the play
therapy room with adjoining observation room, and laundry room. In addition, a two-
section House Supervisor/staff office separates the two halves of the house. The other
half of the house consists of a recreation/day area surrounded by 12 bedrooms. Each
room has one window, a desk and a bed. Youth sleep one boy per room, and all rooms
are in eyesight of the staff office. Another bathroom is adjacent to the back half of the
house.
B. Program Description
The Hainley House program serves male youths ages 8-12 and their families. These
youths are struggling with emotional and behavioral issues to the extent that the youth,
the family and/or the community have been negatively impacted, resulting in the youth
being removed from the home and the community.
2

The Hainley House program accepts youths from the following.
• DHS Delinquents (status offense only).
• DHS County offices (abuse/neglect).
• County Court referrals (abuse, neglect or status offense).
• Adoption Subsidy referrals.
• Private referrals.
• School Referrals.
Residential programming is designed to meet the psychological, emotional, behavioral
and spiritual needs of the youth and family. This is done through the following services:
• Individual/group/family counseling.
• Experiential programming including a 12-day wilderness program, weekend
wilderness programs, community service programs and ropes and towers
initiatives.
• Substance abuse counseling groups (when necessary).
• Psychiatric evaluation (when necessary).
• Psychological testing (when necessary).
• Life skills.
• Educational programming.
• Home visits.
• Voluntary chapel programming including chapel services, youth groups, and
spiritual counseling.
• Family weekends.
Residents attend year round schooling with on-campus school staff through the
Mecosta/Osceola School District. Each classroom is staffed with one special education
teacher and one teacher’s aide. Youth Counselors, House Supervisors and other
personnel provide additional supervision if necessary.
Hainley House has two Family Counselors who develop and manage the overall
treatment of the youths. The Family Counselors are responsible for providing individual,
group and family counseling, and are an integral part of the experiential programming.
Treatment is provided using the cognitive-behavioral and experiential approaches.
There is also a point/level and token economy system that is used primarily as a daily
behavior management tool.
Discharge from the program can occur through Graduation, Escalation, Truancy or
Maximum Benefit. With a discharge due to Graduation, Escalation or Maximum benefit,
the date of termination is established at least 30 days prior to release, so that
transitional counseling and maximizing community support services can occur.
3

C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The Eagle Village Hainley House program was reviewed as part of the overall Eagle
Village, Inc. residential licensing review conducted February 5 and 6 and March 6,
2007. All identified rule violations have been corrected, and the facility is in compliance
with all applicable rule areas.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that an Original Provisional License be issued, effective 9/4/2007.
